source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: Interlaboratory # 1, each laboratory used its own test procedure. The large scatter in data is attributed primarily to differences in autoclave start-up techniques, with minor contributions from variations in pickling time, and residual oxygen remaining in the autoclaves.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: Decreased corrosion of annealed 2.5Nb zirconium with time is attributed to the monotectoid transformation of Nb enriched βZr to αZr plus βNb

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: this alloy oxidizes much faster in high-temperature water and steam-containing oxygen, than in de-oxygenated environments

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 sheet was cut into numbered blocks. Each participating laboratory was supplied with three sets of randomly selected triplicate samples which were: (a) "annealed" material as supplied by the manufacturer

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: (b) "sensitized" at Bettis Atomic Power Laboratories by heating in vacuo for 8 h at 900 C (1650 F), furnace-cooled at 2 C/min to 316 C (600 F), then air-cooled to room temperature
process_step: heat treatment: 900°C/8h vacuo, furnace cool 2°C/min to 316°C, air cool

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk1

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_026_chunk3
evidence_span: Fourteen-day exposures of sensitized and reactor-grade Zircaloy revealed that the venting temperature influenced corrosion response. With water starts, venting at temperatures up to 150 C (300 F) resulted in lower weight gains than venting at 316 C (600 F)
